segment.source: Administer AppLocker (Windows 10)
segment.target: Administer AppLocker (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals provides links to specific procedures to use when administering AppLocker policies.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals provides links to specific procedures to use when administering AppLocker policies.

segment.source: Administer AppLocker
segment.target: Administer AppLocker

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals provides links to specific procedures to use when administering AppLocker policies.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals provides links to specific procedures to use when administering AppLocker policies.

segment.source: AppLocker helps administrators control how users can access and use files, such as executable files, packaged apps, scripts, Windows Installer files, and DLLs.
segment.target: AppLocker helps administrators control how users can access and use files, such as executable files, packaged apps, scripts, Windows Installer files, and DLLs.

segment.source: Using AppLocker, you can:
segment.target: Using AppLocker, you can:

segment.source: Define rules based on file attributes derived from the digital signature, including the publisher, product name, file name, and file version.
segment.target: Define rules based on file attributes derived from the digital signature, including the publisher, product name, file name, and file version.

segment.source: For example, you can create rules based on the publisher attribute that is persistent through updates, or you can create rules for a specific version of a file.
segment.target: For example, you can create rules based on the publisher attribute that is persistent through updates, or you can create rules for a specific version of a file.

segment.source: Assign a rule to a security group or an individual user.
segment.target: Assign a rule to a security group or an individual user.

segment.source: Create exceptions to rules.
segment.target: Create exceptions to rules.

segment.source: For example, you can create a rule that allows all Windows processes to run, except Registry Editor (regedit.exe).
segment.target: For example, you can create a rule that allows all Windows processes to run, except Registry Editor (regedit.exe).

segment.source: Use audit-only mode to deploy the policy and understand its impact before enforcing it.
segment.target: Use audit-only mode to deploy the policy and understand its impact before enforcing it.

segment.source: Import and export rules.
segment.target: Import and export rules.

segment.source: The import and export affects the entire policy.
segment.target: The import and export affects the entire policy.

segment.source: For example, if you export a policy, all of the rules from all of the rule collections are exported, including the enforcement settings for the rule collections.
segment.target: For example, if you export a policy, all of the rules from all of the rule collections are exported, including the enforcement settings for the rule collections.

segment.source: If you import a policy, the existing policy is overwritten.
segment.target: If you import a policy, the existing policy is overwritten.

segment.source: Simplify creating and managing AppLocker rules by using AppLocker PowerShell cmdlets.
segment.target: Simplify creating and managing AppLocker rules by using AppLocker PowerShell cmdlets.

segment.source: Note For more info about enhanced capabilities of AppLocker to control Windows apps, see Packaged apps and packaged app installer rules in AppLocker.
segment.target: Note For more info about enhanced capabilities of AppLocker to control Windows apps, see Packaged apps and packaged app installer rules in AppLocker.

segment.source: Working with AppLocker policies
segment.target: Working with AppLocker policies

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals provides links to procedural topics about creating, maintaining, and testing AppLocker policies.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals provides links to procedural topics about creating, maintaining, and testing AppLocker policies.

segment.source: Using the MMC snap-ins to administer AppLocker
segment.target: Using the MMC snap-ins to administer AppLocker

segment.source: You can administer AppLocker policies by using the Group Policy Management Console to create or edit a Group Policy Object (GPO), or to create or edit an AppLocker policy on a local computer by using the Local Group Policy Editor snap-in or the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc).
segment.target: You can administer AppLocker policies by using the Group Policy Management Console to create or edit a Group Policy Object (GPO), or to create or edit an AppLocker policy on a local computer by using the Local Group Policy Editor snap-in or the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc).

segment.source: Administer Applocker using Group Policy
segment.target: Administer Applocker using Group Policy

segment.source: You must have Edit Setting permission to edit a GPO.
segment.target: You must have Edit Setting permission to edit a GPO.

segment.source: By default, members of the Domain Admins group, the Enterprise Admins group, and the Group Policy Creator Owners group have this permission.
segment.target: By default, members of the Domain Admins group, the Enterprise Admins group, and the Group Policy Creator Owners group have this permission.

segment.source: Also, the Group Policy Management feature must be installed on the computer.
segment.target: Also, the Group Policy Management feature must be installed on the computer.

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).

segment.source: Locate the GPO that contains the AppLocker policy to modify, right-click the GPO, and then click Edit.
segment.target: Locate the GPO that contains the AppLocker policy to modify, right-click the GPO, and then click Edit.

segment.source: In the console tree, double-click Application Control Policies, double-click AppLocker, and then click the rule collection that you want to create the rule for.
segment.target: In the console tree, double-click Application Control Policies, double-click AppLocker, and then click the rule collection that you want to create the rule for.

segment.source: Administer AppLocker on the local PC
segment.target: Administer AppLocker on the local PC

segment.source: Click Start, type local security policy, and then click Local Security Policy.
segment.target: Click Start, type local security policy, and then click Local Security Policy.

segment.source: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.
segment.target: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.

segment.source: In the console tree of the snap-in, double-click Application Control Policies, double-click AppLocker, and then click the rule collection that you want to create the rule for.
segment.target: In the console tree of the snap-in, double-click Application Control Policies, double-click AppLocker, and then click the rule collection that you want to create the rule for.

segment.source: Using Windows PowerShell to administer AppLocker
segment.target: Using Windows PowerShell to administer AppLocker

segment.source: For how-to info about administering AppLocker with Windows PowerShell, see Use the AppLocker Windows PowerShell Cmdlets.
segment.target: For how-to info about administering AppLocker with Windows PowerShell, see Use the AppLocker Windows PowerShell Cmdlets.

segment.source: For reference info and examples how to administer AppLocker with Windows PowerShell, see the AppLocker cmdlets.
segment.target: For reference info and examples how to administer AppLocker with Windows PowerShell, see the AppLocker cmdlets.
